61 OSYM
Operating System Monitoring

OSYM, OSYM General
61.1 OSYM General
� General Information
Abstract
The package operating system monitoring function provides access to information on operating system
related monitoring functionality.
Description of containing functionality:
Operating system monitoring function is intended to be used during development for having a better insight
into the operating system state.
Information on lost task activations and the worst case stack usage are included within the operating system
monitoring function.
The amount of required stack is an important dynamic aspect which has to be considered during development
phase. Stack monitoring is used to analyze the maximal used stack size at runtime.
Operating system monitoring function provides information on lost task activation in case the operating sys-
tem is overloaded or wrongly con?gured. In such a situation it can occur that task activation gets lost. Oper-
ating system monitoring function provides information on the last lost task activation and counts the number
of lost task activations
All data are available in application system and for applicative software. Data which corresponds to the soft-
ware life cycle are available in non volatile memory.

OSYM, OSYM Con?guration data
� General Information
Operatingsystem Monitoring is a set of functionalties to monitor critical parameter of the hole system. These
are:
- Maximum Stack consumption
- Lost Task tracking
- Time monitoring
Additional OSYM expands the OS by follwoing functionalities:
- Periodic Task Activatior: downscales an applied recurrent event and activates the associated tasks.
- Message Passing: For transfering data accross different priority level
- Critical Section protection. For protecting sequences within OS-tasks from being preempted by another
OS-task.
61.2.1 Enabled Package Funcitonality
With this switches the available modules of the OSYM package can be choosen. The OSYM package contains
of:
-Max used Stack Monitoring (SM)
- Lost Task tracking (OSEH)
- periodic task activator (PTA)
- time monitoring ?
- message passing (MEPA)
- critical section (CriSe)

OSYM, Visible data of operating system monitoring functions
61.3 Visible data of operating system monitoring functions
� Data De?nition
Name Mode Coded Limits Display Limits Resolution Unit
CTR_LOSS_TSK_ECU_RUN_CYC O/V 0... FFFFH 0... 65535 1 -
Number of task losses within the ECU running cycle. The ECU running cycle corresponds to the time between end of reset phase
and the end of the power latch phase. This counter does not overrun.
CTR_LOSS_TSK_SW_CYC O/V/S 0... FFFFH 0... 65535 1 -
Number of task losses within the SW life cycle or since erasing. This counter does not overrun.
LF_STATE_OS_TSK_LOSS_ECU_CYC [NC_NR_TSK] O/V 0... FFFFFFFFH 0... 4294967295 1 -
Operating system status information: Bit?eld indicating which task activations are lost within the current ECU running cycle. The ECU
running cycle corresponds to the time since power up.
LF_STATE_OS_TSK_LOSS_PREV [NC_NR_TSK] O/V 0... FFFFFFFFH 0... 4294967295 1 -
Operating system status information: Bit?eld indicating the task activation which is is lost last within the current ECU running cycle.
In case no task is lost within the current ECU running cycle no bit is set.
LF_STATE_OS_TSK_LOSS_SW_CYC [NC_NR_TSK] O/V/S 0... FFFFFFFFH 0... 4294967295 1 -
Operating system status information: Bit?eld indicating which task activations are lost within the SW life cycle or since erasing. The
SW life cycle corresponds to the time since the last SW reprogramming.
STACK_CNS [NC_NR_STACK] O/V/S 0... FFH 0... 100 0.3921569 %
Table of maximum used stack in percent
� Import actions:
ACTION_ARSD_StoreEnvData(IN <FailureType>, IN <FailureSubType>)
� FUNCTION DESCRIPTION:
� General information:
Operating system monitoring functions is intended to provide a framework for setting up parts of the dynamic
system behavior as well as to allow better insight into the operating system state like lost task activations and
worst case stack usage.
61.3.1 Worst case stack usage monitoring
Stack monitoring function has the approach to determine the worst case stack usage. Polling the stack pointer
will show the worst stack usage only when you check the stack pointer in the deepest nesting level. This is
unfortunately not known and therefore it cannot be guaranteed that this approach shows the worst case
stack usage. Instead another approach is used. A "drag indicator" mechanism is used to show the most stack
usage.
The drag indicator mechanism is based on an initialization of the stack with a particular pattern (e.g. 0xABCD-
DCBA). This pattern will be visible on a particular stack position as long as this stack position is not used. In
case a certain stack position is used the pattern gets overwritten. So it is possible to determine the maximum
stack usage even if the data pushed on the stack is already popped and the stack pointer is pointing again to
the start of the stack.
File: 1T90AP01.00B
23887Project: VW SIMOS 18.1 EA888 Document key: 10213413 SPE 000 DE
Baseline: SC8L50Y0 Copyright Continental AG

Copyright �Continental AG. Transmittal, reproduction, dissemination and/or editing of this document as well as utilisation of its contents and communication thereof to others without
expressed authorisation are prohibited. Offenders will be held liable for payment of damages. All rights created by patent grant or registration of a utility model or design patent are reserved.
OSYM, Visible data of operating system monitoring functions
 
The used stack could be determined by checking for the pattern which was written during the initialization
into the stack.
By counting the stack locations where the pattern is equal to the initialization pattern the not yet used stack
could be determined. The worst case stack usage can be determined by subtracting the free location from
the stack size.
Due to the fact that the pattern is after the usage permanently overwritten the worst case stack usage can
even be determined some time after the real worst case stack usage situation occurred. Therefore worst case
stack usage can be determined in background. This is important for not creating additional CPU load.
Stack monitoring is only available if NLC_STACK_MON_ENA is set to 1.
61.3.2 Lost task activation monitoring
Complex control software can conveniently be subdivided into parts executed according to their real-time
requirements. Within an OSEK operating system different code segments can be executed quasi-parallel (multi-
tasking). Code segments parts can be implemented by the means of tasks. A task provides the framework
for the execution of functions. The operating system supports concurrent and asynchronous execution of
tasks. The scheduler within the operating system organizes the sequence of task execution based on the
assigned priority (precedence) to the task. The basic principle of the scheduling mechanism can be perceived
as a framework consisting of a number of FIFO (First-In-First-Out), each assigned to a priority level. If a code
segment should be executed the corresponding task gets introduced at the end of the FIFO assigned to the
task priority level. The scheduler determines the next task to run. The scheduler checks starting from the FIFO
assigned to the highest priority level towards the FIFO assigned to the currently processed priority level if the
FIFO are not empty. If one of the FIFO is not empty the task which is waiting longest gets processed.
File: 1T90AP01.00B
23888Project: VW SIMOS 18.1 EA888 Document key: 10213413 SPE 000 DE
Baseline: SC8L50Y0 Copyright Continental AG

Copyright �Continental AG. Transmittal, reproduction, dissemination and/or editing of this document as well as utilisation of its contents and communication thereof to others without
expressed authorisation are prohibited. Offenders will be held liable for payment of damages. All rights created by patent grant or registration of a utility model or design patent are reserved.
OSYM, Visible data of operating system monitoring functions
 
The activation of tasks is based on events. If an event occurs which requires introducing a task into a FIFO then
it has to be checked, that no FIFO over?ow occurs. For each task it is possible to de?ne how much instances of
this task are allowed to be introduced on the FIFO. In case this number of allowed task activation is exceeded
the task activation gets lost.
� Formula section:
Lost task activation monitoring is available if NLC_OS_TSK_LOSS_MON_ENA is set to 1.
61.3.3 Time monitoring
For various use cases (e.g. the response time between the activation of a certain task and termination of the
task execution, the time between two consecutive executions of the same task...) time duration may have to
be mesured.
For measuring time duration a start and stop interface is provided:
ICS_OSYM_TmStartDurMeas(Obj_Ref)
ICS_OSYM_TmStopDurMeas(Obj_Ref, User_Param)
When the end of the duration is indicated by calling the stop interface function ICS_OSYM_TmStopDurMeas, a
hook is called which passes the object reference and the measured time duration OSYM_TmPassDur(Obj_Ref,
T_Dur, User_Param). Project speci?c evaluation and reactions can be placed within this hook.
In case a measurement for a particular object shall be stopped a reset interface is available:
ICS_OSYM_TmClearDurMeas(Obj_Ref)
Time monitoring functionality is only available if NC_T_MON_ENA = 1

� General Information
61.4.1 Stack Limit exceeded
� General Information
For internal validation purposes a reaction on exceedance of an upper stack limit can be de?ned.
� Application Conditions
Activation: function is called if the stack usage exceeds the limit configured
within NC_STACK_CNS_LIM[NC_NR_STACK]
61.4.2 Task Activation hook
� General Information
For internal validation purposes a task activation hook is de?ned.
� Application Conditions
Activation: (NC_T_MON_ENA = 1) && ((USE_T_RESP_MES_ENA == 1) || (USE_T_
RESP_MON_ENA == 1)) and Periodic Task Activator (PTA) activates
task
61.4.3 PTA-Task Activation function
� General Information
Because of the alternative Task activation of the TASK_F1_SES, this task needs to know who activated it (FlexRay
driver or PTA). This information is transferred to the task with OSYM_MEPA functionality. In order to be able
to activate the time periodic tasks directly with the task activation mechanism of the used OS and sending
a OSYM_MEPA message with task activation to the FlexRay task a controller function is need.
This function replaces the direct call of the OS-task activation API by an project speci?c OSYM-API.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: none
Activation: always active
Recurrence: every PTA-Task activation at miminmum every 1ms

61.4.4 Time monitoring hook
� General Information
For internal validation purposes a time monitoring evaluation routine is de?ned.
� Application Conditions
Activation: NC_T_MON_ENA = 1
Recurrence: called in ICS_OSYM_TmStopDurMeas
� Function Description
5. Task startup measurement:
If USE_T_TSK_RAMP_UP_MES_ENA= 1 the time span from end of reset task till the time synchronous tasks are
dispatched the next time.
Output data:
The number of elements of this array depends on the con?gured PTA-tasks with response time monitoring.
Name Mode Hex. Limits Phys. Limits Resol. Unit
osym_t_task_start_up[number
of pta-tasks]
V 0..FFFFFFFF 0..4294967.295 0.001 ms
Array for the Rampup times
The startup measurement is started in the reset Task right before the lv_rst_end is set to 1. This is done for
all PTA-Tasks with the APIsICS_OSYM_TmStartRampupMes() at once. The measurement is stopped for each
task individually by calling at the beginning of the task: ICS_OSYM_TmStopRampupMes().
61.4.5 ACTION_OSYM_MepaSendU8WRespTime
This ACTION sends a OSYM_MEPA message of the data type U8. If OSYM_TM Response time measurement
or monitoring is enabled it starts a response time measurement of the TM-Object with the index stored in the
user parameter of the OSYM_MEPA message. In case the message could not be send for the associated task
a entry in OSEH is made. In case of a invalid parameter (respectively a NULL pointer) the OSYM_ErrorHook is
called.

61.4.6 ACTION_OSYM_StartNewRunCycle
At the development of OSYM it was assumed that ACTION_OSYM_EndEcuRunCycle will be only called after
the point of no return in the power latch sequence. So the run cycle data weren?t cleared after updating the
SW life cycle data.
In this project the NVMY-data is started to be stored much before the point of no return. So ACTION_OSYM_En-
dEcuRunCycle has be called at entering the PWL-Phase. But PWL can be left without a reset. In this case tasks
which have been lost in the pervious run cycle would be counted twice to the SW live cycle counter. In order to
prevent this behavior this action is provided. It shall be called directly after ACTION_OSYM_EndEcuRunCycle.
